reviews.review_msg: awful. just awful.

Run.  Take any other professor than Thomas.  Be prepared to have disorganized slides.  Be prepared to hear lectures about his personal career and life and nothing else.  The material itself is not difficult whatsoever, but he makes it convoluted and confusing.

Thomas is a nice person but his class is useless, it's a group therapy self improvement course that talks about ethics in business occasionally. In our final report, only 1/3 was ethics, the rest was felt like a 10 year olds diary of what he wants to be when he grows up, and some self reflection about “moral foundation” values. Money well spent.

The biggest waste of time and money. When you think of business ethics you think maybe you could learn something interesting but this was not the case. Tom is delusional when it comes to the fact he believes world peace will come with meditation. This class should automatically be removed and tom should not be teaching a business course.

He's a nice prof, I liked his lectures. However, his class felt more like meditation-group-therapy than an actual business ethics class. I  do get the idea behind it, but as someone who was actually excited to take a real business ethics course, I found it to be misleading. I also dislike how missing 3 classes fails you, even being late is noted.

It seemed he used his platform as a business ethics professor to teach about his own worldviews rather than business ethics itself. Tom's entire course is an application of Meditation, Daoism, and mindfulness to ethical thinking, which is not the worst thing to learn, but rarely has anything to do with business ethics in general.

Took a whole ethics class, yet learned nothing about ethics. Class is entirely useless. Thomas is a nice guy but his classes are painstakingly boring. Trys to teach you his own fringe belief of what ethics should be instead of what is actually useful and true. Makes you meditate every class, and is incredibly unorganized.
Super boring lectures, bad presentations. However, the readings are interesting.

Not a typical business class, but sometimes change is good. Tom is a super sweet man, though his grading is always super vague. The class content was very simple, though there were many repetitive assignments that made the class dry. Lots of discussion which makes the class more interesting.

Thomas takes an abstract approach to ethics that many business students can't comprehend and are quick to hate on. If you come into his class with an open mind, you will understand his journal and meditation sessions are extremely beneficial to ethical decision-making.

Thomas definitely is passionate about his job and cares deeply about his students. However, he is unable to effectively organize and operate his lesson plans. His business classes utilize non-business activities such as meditation and "feeling" journals. None of these practices relate in the slightest to business. Big waste of time.

Tom believes business schools do not teach ethics in a way which prepares students for the real world. In an attempt to "change the way business is done" (his words from his PhD paper), he focuses on teaching students the importance of emotional intelligence and meditation. Ironic, as these have little to do with ethics.

I can not believe this is a business class. This is a psych class mixed with ethics and morals and emotions and a bunch of other stuff. This is not a business class. I wish SFU made this an elective for people trying to try new things out. Class was sooooo boring I can't believe I paid money for this class.

Tom has a sort of hippy-dippy approach to business ethics, focussing on personal ethics how to improve your EI and decision-making skills. He was one of the most engaging profs I've had at SFU, very passionate about the lecture content and does what he can to support the success of his students.
Nice guy, but expects way too much from students. Classes are dull and boring, attendance is mandatory, there are class presentations and unreasonable assignments especially the last one.

This is the most useless business course you will ever take. You are paying money to sit in a room and meditate. He is just going into random articles that he find and deems relevant. 2 8-10 pages assigned in the last two weeks of the course with little no information provided beforehand. SFU remove this course and let your students save money.

Tom is an extremely caring and respectful professor who cares about his student's wellbeing. He replies to emails promptly. However, his lectures are extremely dull and there is mediation and presentations every class. There are also 3 papers during the semester and they are 5-10 pages minimum. Get ready to write!

He cares about his student's success but his lectures are disorganized. Assignment due dates are not outlined in the so called "syllabus". He disrespects student's time. He assigned 3 papers (8-10 pages) to be completed within 4 weeks of each other at the end of the semester. Space them out over the course of the 12 weeks, not 4 weeks!! Stressful!

Thomas is a good professor in the sense that he cares about his students and wants them to do well. However, he is super disorganized with his lectures and goes off tangent a lot by sharing personal stories. Far too many useless assignments/journal entries to do and his exams are way more in-depth than what he goes over in the lectures.

He focused on helping you develop and finding who you are. Although there is lots of meditation and reflections about yourself, he does it for your own good. He wants to see you succeed and puts in the effort to do do. He doesn't teach ethics, but rather it's a journey about finding yourself. Definitely recommend Tom.
horrible class.. need to buy 3 textbooks, one of them being his which makes ABSOLUTELY NO SENSE. I need to meditate every 5 minutes because I feel the urge to rip this textbook apart if I don't.

Lectures are mandatory but completely useless. Meditation is required at the beginning of the class. Thomas is a nice person and means really well, but doesn't understand students and is unorganized with canvas.

Super easy professor, focuses the class more on yourself and personal development rather than actual business ethics. Compared to other professors he is a lot easier and the material is not as dry. No final with him and the midterm was really easy. Requires journal articles and what you have learnt from that week. Also makes you meditate in class.

His class was all about feelings and getting to know thyself. Barf. In-class meditations (good chance for nap). Weekly reflections/journal entries and online group discussions. If you miss any discussions, your marks for all the other ones you did gets lowered. You have to be good at explaining your deepest values in writing and with lots of detail
Really cool guy. Put a lot of effort into this class. Winks like sarah palin. Am sure class will get better as he gathers more examples.
Skip the lectures and read the textbook. If you go to lectures you're wasting your time. Slides are absolutely useless. Really hard to stay awake (except for videos).
No Comments
No Comments

While I applaud his effort in making his own slides, they're useless unless you add onto them. Maybe next time he teaches this course he'll actually provide an outline for the group project instead of making it up as he goes along. He made the course much easier after the midterm: A 60% average increased to a 78% average after the final.

He does not teach BUSINESS ethics, he simply teaches ethics with SOME business examples.  I was thoroughly disappointed with the inconsistency of his marking. "Group" project and final exam were marked too leniently, and did not sufficiently provide a  somewhat concrete distribution of grades. Positives: lots of videos, great to keep you awake.
At the beginning it was a boring class, but later it became more interesting. He makes it seem much more interesting. Lecture notes make no sense without the lecture.

The course is ethics. It WILL be boring but he makes it bearable with stories. Notes make absolutely no sense on their own; they don't flow without lecture notes. Or just read the text since slides seem to made from the text. Marking is a bit tough but he's consistently harsh and it's on a curve. Good prof, light workload, lousy subject
No Comments

Attendance is not necessary but participation makes a huge bit out of the final grade so definitely go to class. No tutorials for this class but there seems to be a lot of emphasis on reading. LOTS of reading. She is a little messy but is kind and approachable. Class often gets moved to zoom at the last minute or starts late. Very chill overall.

Sara clearly cares about her students doing well, judging by the amount of work and reading.  Showing up and talking in class is a big part of your grade, so definitely go.  That said, class often starts late or gets cancelled, which can make the course feel less intense overall.
Cancelled class first few weeks. Unclear criteria with no feedback. Wouldn't reply to emails on time. Would give 0 if possible.
VERY unclear marking/criteria. assignments were handed back with no feedback, so didn't know how to improve. lectures are always disorganized.

Sara is an outstanding educator who genuinely cares about her students. Her lectures are fascinating and captivating, and they push you to reflect carefully about morality, the ego, and how it affects you and the rest of the world. She offers you high-quality criticism and all the tools you need to advance both academically and personally.
Extremely unorganized, often shows up to class late with little notice, ambiguous assignments and grading criteria. Sara is a nice person, but her teaching style seems very inexperienced.

Sara is a phenomenal professor that truly cares about her students. Her lectures are interesting and engaging and they force you to think deeply about ethics, the ego, and how it impacts you and the world. She provides quality feedback and gives you every resource to improve both as a student and on a personal level as an individual. Sara is a gem.

Absolutely the most lazy and boring professor I've ever had. Two group projects, two papers, and two evaluation on the two other groups. They were marked unfairly because he only accepts HIS answers. Just do yourself a favour and don't take this class with him.

There is so much to do in his class. 2 group presenations and 2 case studies and a final. His lectures are boring as he reads the slide for half the class and students presentations for the other half. He expects you to know everything for the final. Lecture slides and info from presentations which is unfair as most are poorly done.

Ethics is a boring class already, yet he made the class even more boring. There were so many things you needed to do: a case on a book or an article, a debate, evaluations on other groups, two individual assignments, and a final exam. Lectures slides were very wordy and he basically read off the slides. He used full 3 hours with a 10 mins break.

One of the most relaxed business profs i've ever had. He is nice and approachable, but always late by 20 minutes. It was alright for me since i get to sleep in for a few extra minutes. Not all readings are useful, focus more on his notes. His midterms deviate little from previous semesters and are straight from powerpoints.

Take a class with him! He's very nice and his exams and assignments are completely fair.  High overall class marks mean that the class will be scaled down.  Makes boring content interesting with random tangents and interesting side stories.  Focus on lecture material (don't bother with textbook) for 303.  I would love to take a class with him again

Really nice guy, he seems to genuinely care, unfortunately he also is a bit of a scatter brain and goes on many tangents, making the class hard to follow.  In my term he marked too easily and ended up having to curve everyone down drastically, a bit of a shock when 70ish becomes low C's and 90s are A-'s.
great prof. he's really enthusiastic about the material and tries hard to make a not-so-interesting class interesting.
Easy prof...boring, but relatively easy

This is surely one of the worst profs I have ever had. Once he finally obtained the teachers guide his midterms finally made sense. From then one it was simple. The format of his lecture notes is questionable. Severely boring. His favroite word: "um".

Please take ethics from someone else! He lectures' aren't clear & he makes totally off-topic jokes which are irrelevant to the course. In the end, nobody laughs and no point comes across. Midterms r hard n case studies r marked brutally hard. HE WILL get ur frustrated!

Jason Ho is an awesome prof! His lectures are very engaging and he is hilarious! He wants the best for his students and tries to give out as many A's as possible. Always available for help. Definitely take marketing with him!

One of the best classes! More learning with less stress for a theoretical course on Ethics. All the information was easily accessible. No need to buy books. Just be attentive and follow the guidelines. She is nice. You'll enjoy the skits.

genuinely one of the most disorganized classes i have ever taken, no clear grading, just zero vibes and running on some class activities. meditation is the only thing I learned from this course, GPA booster? lol.
Intelligent professor, fair with grading, popular yet so down to earth. Sadly, she does not teach other courses. I will miss her classes.

Neha is very nice and always ready to support. I find her classes balanced with interactive lectures, group activities, 10 min meditation. As someone who struggles with anxiety, I was worried about taking a course on ethics but felt comfortable from the very first class with her. Overall, a life-transforming course for me. Attendance is required.

Neha was a nice professor, and she was very enthusiastic, but the class felt like a joke. Neha was quite disorganized and would often ramble about random ethics jargon. It never really feels like you are truly learning something useful. You don't need to study much in this class either, but participation is mandatory.

lectures are so dry and boring to survive through, and the prof is so disorganized. the way she words things is so confusing. the class itself is okay overall, its just weekly journals, a group skit, and a midterm/final. take it if you don't have any better choices

One of the more underrated professors from Beedie, assignments are fairly straightforward and be sure to keep up with weekly assignments, journaling and participation and you should be fine for the most part.

All you need to do is go to class, do the class, do mediation, write the weekly journals and nail the assessments. She's chill with deadlines but show her respect for her teaching and the you can easily score a B without having to overextend yourself. I personally took a lot away in terms of learning to be a better person overall.

Went to her first lecture today and she seems super sweet and understanding. Asked us to let her know if we want to change anything in the syllabus which is quite unheard of with most profs. Near the end of class we did 5 minutes of mindfulness/meditation. No midterm but there is a final. Assignments don't seem like they will be too hard!
He is extremely chilled and easy going. Also a really nice guy. Class is too easy to be on a curve.

There really isn't anything to study in this course. Getting an B+/A- is incredibly easy, but doing any better than that seems impossible because of the curve. He has a dry sense of humour, which is at times funny, and other times rude.

Good lectures and funny prof, but be warned; he is ideologically possessed, very old school, rude when you talk to him or approach for questions. Take James Pflanz instead, at least he doesn't yell at me over the phone when i request office hours.

The professor i came across as an international student in canada. He cares for students and has a good sense of humour. I took this course bcoz i have intrest in law and the lectures were so intresting. Highly recommended without a doubt he is the best and knowledgeable.
Best professor in Beedie.

I took Bus 303 this semester with professor bhalloo and honestly all of the reviews on here are very accurate. I am not a morning person but still found myself attending his Friday morning lectures. He is super funny, approachable and uses real life scenarios to make the course engaging. 1 midterm, 1 final and a group project!

Shafik was a great prof that explained concepts clearly and did a really good job enforcing your learning. He covered topics in a fashion that keeps people entertained and interested. I really enjoyed his class!! There was no homework other than 1 group project (+ 1 midterm and 1 final), which means the workload is light (and they aren't hard too).

I like his style of teaching business ethics. I took both bus law and bus ethics with him and I. Both classes he was consistent. Very clear and easy to understand. I think the final was a bit difficult but he marked it very fairly . He genuinely wants you to succeed in class and is always available for help. My favourite teacher at Beedie

I was a little scared of taking this course but I had Shafiq for Bus Law An day loved it. What made this course excellently was his style of teaching and also his examples and how he interacted with us in class. Ed is re spectrum Andy very fair but also kind
Good teacher but lectures are a bit on the longer side sometimes. He could give a longer break in the class. Examples are very good but some examples a bit too long

Taking business ethics and also business law with him at SFU. His classes are always full, even the early morning one on Tuesday at 8:30 . He comes very prepared to perform. He is very good and has a way of making material interesting and enjoyable with real examples. He is always available to help, even okay taking calls at his office.

Shafiq is an ecellent prof. Very caring and smart. I took his business ethics class and found him very good at explaning difficult concepts with examples. Fair marker. He loves people participating and very good at getting people to participate. Very respectful. I am taking bus 393 with him in the fall. Just got in his class. Was on waitlist.

Amazing lectures, easy to understand, always prepared and very engaging. I will take him again in ethics course business 303. I wish he would soon teach employment Law course. My friend took his employment course and said he was excellent.

I had prof Shafiq for bus 303 and enjoyed it so much that I have him for BUS393. He make law and ethics very easy to understand and he has really good example to break things down in bite sizes to make you understand. His lectures are really good. I am there at 8:30 in the morning. Not many classes in the last 3 years I have woken up for at 8:30

Amazing lectures. He is excellent and easy to listen to and super smart. Knows his stuff. Had him in commercial law and then in business ethics course last summer. Would take any of his classes as he is my favourite prof at SFU Beedie. Very approachable and always available to you. Treats you like a human being.

I like Shafiks lecture, never skip one class and understand the basic concepts of bus 303. The grade is straight forward, one midterm and one final assignment, same format, very similar to the example midterm. Practice and ask him. Be free to provide own experience to him at last question. But the average is high, got 82%, and maybe around median

I like shafik because his lectures are very clear and he knows what he is talking about. Gives real world examples to make his point. He makes boring stuff exciting. He is honestly interested interested in making students comfortable and encourages us to participate in class. In the 3 years at school, I have to say he is the best prof I have had.

Taking both his courses this semester: business 393 commercial law and business 303 ethics. He is the best prof to take in both courses but it is difficult to get into his class. I got in last minute when the department opened the course and allowed some of the people on his huge waitlist to register. You have to take him.

He makes everything very simple and straightforward. 1 midterm, 1 group assignment, 1 final with SAME FORMAT! He explains the theories over and over + also breaks down structure of assignments with crystal clarity. If you didn't get a high mark in this class, then something's wrong with you not him. I couldn't have asked for a better prof for 303.

Heard that ethics is confusing and hard to get good grades before taking. However, Shafik does his best to make the class so straightforward and easy to follow. No need to read the book as his lecture notes included everything. It is good to attend classes to clarify confusions and listen to his examples. One of my best prof at SFU :)

303 is pretty straightforward. Teaching style is relaxed and friendly. Is always super open to students reaching out to him for questions. Pretty subjective class. 80% average on MT and 80% on assignment. Hard to get a high mark due to high curve.

I laughed, I cried, I laughed again.  That has nothing to do with the class, I'm just bipolar. Shafik is terrific, his skill at making a point clear through his stories is awesome. He made sure to get to know almost everyone and we all felt more involved because of it.

Totally awesome prof. I find his lectures very informative and so much practical info. It helps being able to lecture like he does. He is an excellent story teller and tons of examples to make you understand materials. Definitely most interesting class I have had.

I too 393 and 303 with him and found him equally excellent in both classes. He is very clear and like all here his examples are very good. If you did not do well it is because you are lazy or not smart. He goes out of his way to help you. Excellent teach for sure.
